Dirty, add newlines before each METADATA except first:

    cat F_Worker_TEMP_VO.dat ....dat | sed 's/\(.\)METADATA/\1\nMETADATA/g' > Worker.dat

Loop:

    for file in F_Worker_TEMP_VO.dat ... F_PERSON_NATIONALIDE_SSN_TEMP_VO.dat; do

I believe that this StackOverflow answer covers all that you might need:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8183191/concatenating-files-and-insert-new-line-in-between-files

Anyways, here is the command you want:
```
for f in *.dat; do (cat "${f}"; echo) >> finalfile.dat; done
```
Or use an array if you want to concatenate only a Subset of files in some order. Sed and Awk uses are also in the linked StackOverflow answer.

answers.body_markdown:
The reason why is because filters are not meant to be used in a `v-html` directive. When doing so, `marked` is looked upon properties/methods of the component, which is, indeed, not declared (since it's a filter).

The only ways for you are to move `marked` to `data()` or `methods{}` or even better, build a computed property out of it (so it's cached).

It could have been possible _if_ there was a `{{{ }}}` in the template engine, but as there's not, what you want to achieve is impossible.

---

PS: the example you mentioned is working because it's using **Vue v1.0** ; only updating the dependencies would make that fiddle fail.

answers.body_markdown:
In general `select` and `pull` work with both raw column names (Q1) and string column names ("Q1"), but `filter`, `mutate`, ... expect raw column names. 

Under the assumption you are really only interested in the number of "Every day" in your question you can do with base R: 

    my_function_base <- function(survey, question_number) {
      
      sum(survey[[question_number]] %in% "Every day")
      
    }
    
    my_function_base(my_df, "Q2")
    # [1] 1


There are several possibilities to fix your dplyr function, but here are two options. 

    library(dplyr)

**Using string input**

    my_function_str <- function(survey, question_number) {
        
      survey %>%
        filter_at(question_number, ~ . == "Every day") %>%
        count()
    }
      
    my_function_str(my_df, "Q2")
    # A tibble: 1 x 1
    #       n
    #   <int>
    # 1     1

`filter_at` works with strings as input and then filters at the specified columns. 

**Using NSE:** See also: https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/articles/programming.html

    my_function_nse <- function(survey, question_number) {
      question_number <- enquo(question_number)
      
      survey %>%
        filter(!!question_number == "Every day") %>%
        count()
    }
    
    my_function_nse(my_df, Q1) # No quotes around Q1

    # A tibble: 1 x 1
    #       n
    #   <int>
    # 1     2

**Data**
 
    my_df <- data.frame(Q1 = c("Every week", "Every day", "Every week", "Every day"), 
                        Q2 = c("Every week", "Every week", "Every week", "Every day"))

The link shared by @zx8754 should be able to help you fix the issue you have. Considering you saying you're new to `R` here is how you can modify your function. 

```r
my_function <- function(df, col) {
  df %>%
    select(col) %>%
    filter((!!as.symbol(col))=="Every day") %>%
    count()
}
# This is how you call your function
my_function(df, "Q1")
```
Where `df` your dataframe, I think it is called `survey` and `col` is the column you want to filter into. 

Hope that helps.

answers.body_markdown:
You can use `ROW_NUMBER()` to rank the records by ascending `T1.DocDate` in a inner query, and then select the oldest in the outer query:

    Select *
    From (
    	Select  
    		T0.ItemCode, 
    		T0.OpenQty as 'Qty', 
    		T1.DocDate,
    		T1.DocNum, 
    		T1.CardCode, 
    		T1.SlpCode as 'Sales Person', 
    		T0.WhsCode,
    		Row_Number() Over(Order By T1.DocDate) rn
    	From RDR1 T0
    	Inner Join ORDR T1 on T0.DocEntry = T1.DocEntry
    	Where T0.linestatus = 'O'
    ) x
    Where rn = 1

This will give you the oldest record in the table. If you need to get the oldest record per group, then you can add a `PARTITION BY` clause to the `ROW_NUMBER()` function. 

Note: this also assumes that `T1.DocDate` is of a date-like datatype, which seems to be (and should be) the case by looking at your sample data.

```
Select  top 10 T0.ItemCode, T0.OpenQty as 'Qty', T1.DocDate as 'DocDate', T1.DocNum, T1.CardCode, T1.SlpCode as 'Sales Person', T0.WhsCode
From RDR1 T0
Where T0.linestatus = 'O'
order by T1.DocDate
```

answers.body_markdown:
Running NPM install twice would only slows your deployment and would not cause any other problems if you don't copy *node_modules* into your Docker container.

Make sure you copy only the source code to the docker container and leave *node_modules* out. You can add a *.dockerignore* file for that:
```
node_modules
npm-debug.log
Dockerfile
.dockerignore
```

This would make sure the packages are installed properly in the Docker container.

AnkhSVN does not support Visual Studio 2019 now. The project is inactive, and in its current state it will not work with Visual Studio 2019 properly.

Consider migrating to [VisualSVN][1] that fully supports Visual Studio 2019. It is **completely free for use on non-domain computers (no registration required)** and provides about the same functionality compared with AnkhSVN. Note that some users find VisualSVN to be much better for their cases.

It is should be very easy to migrate from AnkhSVN to VisualSVN. The most recent [VisualSVN 7.1][2] and [VisualSVN 6.5][3] releases add support for multiple working copies within a single solution, and this makes the migration practically instant and painless for almost all users. See the article [KB58: Migrating from AnkhSVN to VisualSVN][4] for instructions and the article [KB7: Using Multiple Working Copies in VisualSVN][5] if your solution projects span across multiple working copies.

> problem.

Hacking the VS2017 VSIX files by adding a few string to make this VSIX install into VS2019 is a very bad idea. This action does not magically make AnkhSVN support VS2019 - it allows its installation into VS2019. This hack may cause overall Visual Studio destabilization and unexpected problems.

**DISCLAIMER:** I am a support engineer with VisualSVN Team.

answers.body_markdown:
Your `name` data property should have only `Feature` as its domain. `Organism` wouldn't be a domain for this property, in the class hierarchy you're planning to create.

Multiple domains can be used in OWL, but note that using a property with two or more domains means that the individuals appearing as subjects belong to the intersection of the domains. I don't think you wish to create individuals that are instance of both `Organism` and `Feature`.
answers.title: How can we specify values in a class instance in OWL XML?

answers.body_markdown:
Before answering your question, let me tell you that OWL is not an object oriented programming language. You **cannot** model Java classes with OWL. With that said, it is often the case that Java classes correspond to an in-memory representation of something you want to represent knowledge about. Thus, there could be correspondences between an OOP model and an OWL ontology. However, there is no single way of mapping an OOP model to an OWL ontology, and there are pitfalls that should be avoided.

One very common mistake people do when thinking of OWL as an object oriented formalism is to think that classes have attributes, and that attributes or properties belong to a class. In OWL, they don't. While it is sometimes possible to make sense of a sentence like "the property `name` of the class `Organism`", this is as much meaningful in OWL as "the class `Organism` of the property `name`". Classes and properties exist on their own, independently from each other. None belong to the other. However, they can be related in different ways.

Another typical mistake is to misinterpret the relations `domain` and `range` that connect a property to a class. Entities that have a property are typed with *every* domains the property has.

Now, let us go back to your problem. It is very hard to answer your modelling problem without more details about what you are trying to model. As I said, having a Java class is not sufficient to say how the corresponding OWL terms should be defined. For instance, what do you mean with the term "feature"? The attribute `features` of the Java class `Organism` is a list. Is the order important? An `animal_property` is a number?! What is this number representing? Is `name` supposed to be understood in the common sense English word "name"? In my opinion, anything that one can think of can be named, not just organisms or features.

In your case, an intuitive understanding of what you may want have to be guessed based on the choice of English words you've made, and a rough idea of what programming constructs are usually used for. My intuitition is that it is a good idea to map each Java class to an OWL class, and to map inheritance to the `subClassOf` relation.

For properties, it is more complicated. Most Java attributes that have a primitive type map naturally to an OWL datatype property. But not always! OOP classes often contain auxiliary data structures that only make sense for the application logic, yet are irrelevent to the representation of our knowledge of the type of entities. In your model, it is very much possible that the attribute `feature1` in Java class `Features` should not be mapped to an OWL property at all. The `name` attribute in `Organism` could map to the same property as the `name` attribute in `Features`, but possibly not, depending on what you mean. My intuition is that there should be a single `name` property that shoud **not** have any defined domain (such that it could be used safely on any entity).

OOP languages have primitive data types that are very similar to the XML schema datatypes (XSDs). However, the "obvious" mapping is not always the best. With my understanding of the `name` property, I would expect that language tags could be used. If the range is `xsd:string`, then language tagged literals are forbidden.

Based on the name of the property `features` and class `Feature`, I would tend to agree that the range of `features` should be `Feature`, although I do not really understand what `Feature` is supposed to represent. Whether or not the domain should be `Organism` totally depends on what exactly the class `Feature` precisely represents.

Finally, the properties `animal_property` and `plant_property` are mysterious and I have the intuition that they do not represent much of the intrinsic nature of animals and plants. In any case, is there a reason to restrict the size of these integer to fit in an `xsd:int? In general, it is good practice to use `xsd:integer` for numbers that have no particular reason to be bounded. There is no reason to have our representation of knowledge about the world be constrained by the weak 32 bits architectures of our old computers.
answers.title: How can we specify values in a class instance in OWL XML?

answers.title: How to select in range and print if no result on one of the items

answers.body_markdown:
The best long term solution here might be to just maintain a calendar table of all possible `id` value which you would expect using to search.  In lieu of this, we can use an inline subquery:

    SELECT
        t1.id,
        COALESCE(t2.name, 'NO') AS name
    FROM
    (
        SELECT 1 AS id UNION ALL
        SELECT 2 UNION ALL
        SELECT 3 UNION ALL
        -- other numbers
        SELECT 88 UNION ALL
        -- more numbers
        SELECT 99
    ) t1
    LEFT JOIN mytable t2
        ON t1.id = t2.id
    WHERE
        t1.id IN (1, 3, 88, 99)
    ORDER BY
        t1.id;

The strategy here is twofold.  First, we left join the calendar table to your table, retaining all `id` values in the full range.  Then, we restrict to only `id` values you want to see.  For those `id` values which do _not_ appear in your table, the names would show up as `NULL`.
answers.title: How to select in range and print if no result on one of the items

answers.body_markdown:
The row_number() function is usually used to identify the previous rows.

    with cte as (
      select *, row_number() over (order by id) as row
      from table
    )
    select *, 
           (select sum(cte2.balance)
            from cte as cte2
            where cte2.row < cte1.row) as SumBalance
    from cte as cte1
    order by id

Although your id column could already make the same task of identifying the previous rows, so you don't really need the CTE.

    select *, 
           (select sum(cte2.balance)
            from cte as cte2
            where cte2.id < cte1.id) as SumBalance
    from cte as cte1
    order by id

And finally, you could use a variable to store and increment the sum of balances, so you don't even need a subquery.

    declare @SumBalance int = 0

    select *, @SumBalance = @SumBalance + Balance as SumBalance
    from table
    order by id

answers.title: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: org.springframework.context.ApplicationContext

answers.body_markdown:
You can create `ApplicationContext` by 2 ways

**1) XML based:**

`ApplicationContext ctx = new ClassPathXmlApplicationContext("beans.xml");`

Here `beans.xml` contains all the bean definitions.

**2) Annotations based:**

`ApplicationContext context = new AnnotationConfigApplicationContext(ApplicationConfiguration.class);`

Here, `ApplicationConfiguration` is annotated with `@Configuration` annotation.

Also, please make sure that classpath has all the spring jars.

answers.title: Calculate average for preceding multiple periods

answers.body_markdown:
It's messy, but here's another solution:

```sql
WITH cte([PolicyNo], [Quarter], [Claim Grouping], [Year], [Total Claim], [RowNum]) AS (
  SELECT 
    [PolicyNo], [Quarter], [Claim Grouping], [Year], [Total Claim],
    ROW_NUMBER() OVER(
      PARTITION BY [Claim Grouping] ORDER BY [Year], [Quarter] -- Assign "row numbers"
    ) AS [RowNum]
  FROM BaseTabel
)
SELECT DISTINCT 
  src.[PolicyNo], src.[Quarter], src.[Claim Grouping], src.[Year], src.[Total Claim],
  AVG(src.[Total_Claim_prev]) OVER(
    PARTITION BY [Claim Grouping], src.[rownum]
  ) AS [4QuarterAverage]
FROM (
  SELECT 
    cte.[rownum],
    cte.[PolicyNo], 
    cte.[Year], 
    cte.[Quarter], 
    cte.[Claim Grouping],
    cte.[Total Claim], 
    cte2.[total claim] AS [Total_Claim_prev]
  FROM cte
  LEFT JOIN cte AS cte2 ON cte.[Claim Grouping] = cte2.[Claim Grouping]
    AND cte2.[RowNum] BETWEEN cte.[RowNum] - 4 AND cte.[RowNum] - 1 -- Get 4 previous rows
) src
```

Your post says you want the average for the four preceding quarters, but your initial query gives the average of the three preceding quarters (`THREE PRECEDING`) and the current one (`CURRENT ROW`).

This query will give you the average of the four preceding quarters, excluding the current one.

[SQL Fiddle][1]


  [1]: http://sqlfiddle.com/#!18/47ad83/2
answers.title: Calculate average for preceding multiple periods

answers.body_markdown:
When you parse xml using `simplexml_load_file()` it returns an `object` of class `SimpleXMLElement` with properties containing the data held within the XML document, or FALSE on failure.

```PHP
    $phpObject = simplexml_load_file($url);
```

You can directly cast it to `array`: 

```PHP
    $array = (array) $phpObject;
```

or `json`:

```PHP
    $json = json_encode($phpObject);
```

you can check a working exmple here [http://ideone.com/MRMW1E][1]

**It's 100% bug of iOS 13.1 and Xcode 11.0**.

There were no such issues in iOS 12.0, 12.4 and 13.0.

It occurs when I build Metal-based AR apps (like apps for face tracking) on iPad connected to Xcode.

When I disconnect my device from Xcode – the apps launch without any freeze at all.
answers.title: What's the cause of one second freezes on iOS 13 when ARKit calls nextDrawable?

items.body_markdown:
I'm trying to debug a problem with 1-second freezes in ARKit on iOS 13 when `SCNRenderer` calls `[CAMetalLayer nextDrawable]` (which [the documentation][1] does say can freeze for that duration). It's not hard to reproduce the problem but it does only happen randomly about half the time the app is run.

When the problem is occurring there are two rendering queues visible, one marked `ARSCNView` and the other `SCNView`, as shown in this screenshot:

[![queue screenshot][2]][2]

I think the two queues are always there, it's just I only see them when breaking into the debugger when stuck on the `nextDrawable` call.

Only saw this problem when iOS 13.1 came along but it's possible I just missed it on iOS 13. Posting this question hoping someone else is working on the same thing right now...

  [1]: https://developer.apple.com/documentation/quartzcore/cametallayer/1478172-nextdrawable?language=objc
  [2]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/bGQsy.jpg
